page_analysis.text_content:
Fireplaces, chimneys, sheds, planters, and other projections

• Fireplaces shall be included in the gross floor area (counted one time) regardless of configura-
tion or design.
• Sheds, planters, and other projections that are higher than 5' count toward gross floor area
regardless of configuration or design.

Fig 14 Fireplaces, chimneys, sheds, etc.

Note: In 2000, the city of Palo Alto
passed an ordinance prohibiting the
construction of new wood-burning fire-
places. For details about and possible
hibition, see the
ter 9.06.030

Chimneys on the
upper floors DO
NOT COUNT

Height

All configurations of fireplaces, chimneys, and buttresses
COUNT ONCE towards the gross floor area.
Note: Fireplaces not connected to the house are treated
like accessory structures, they and count towards FAR if
they are greater than 120 sf. They count towards lot
coverage always, regardless of size.

Miscellaneous appendages e.g., tool
sheds, equipment enclosures, play
houses, etc., that are greater than 5' in
height, DO COUNT toward gross floor
area. (Note: Neither appendages like
this nor noise-producing equipment may
be located in the required yards).

19

visual_elements.description: An isometric line drawing of a house with multiple chimneys and a small shed-like structure. Arrows and text labels point to specific elements to explain how they are counted for gross floor area, FAR, and lot coverage. One chimney is shown on an upper floor with a 'DO NOT COUNT' label. Another chimney and a buttress are shown at ground level with a label indicating they 'COUNT ONCE towards the gross floor area'. A separate shed-like structure is shown with a 'Height' dimension line and a label explaining that miscellaneous appendages greater than 5' in height 'DO COUNT toward gross floor area'.
visual_elements.location: Middle to bottom of the page

technical_specifications.parameter: Shed/projection height threshold for counting towards gross floor area
Fireplace size threshold for counting towards FAR if not connected to house
Year of Palo Alto ordinance prohibiting new wood-burning fireplaces

structural_elements.main_heading: Fireplaces, chimneys, sheds, planters, and other projections
sections: Note: In 2000, the city of Palo Alto passed an ordinance prohibiting the construction of new wood-burning fire-places. For details about and possible hibition, see the ter 9.06.030
Chimneys on the upper floors DO NOT COUNT
All configurations of fireplaces, chimneys, and buttresses COUNT ONCE towards the gross floor area.

Note: Fireplaces not connected to the house are treated like accessory structures, they and count towards FAR if they are greater than 120 sf. They count towards lot coverage always, regardless of size.

Miscellaneous appendages e.g., tool sheds, equipment enclosures, play houses, etc., that are greater than 5' in height, DO COUNT toward gross floor area. (Note: Neither appendages like this nor noise-producing equipment may be located in the required yards).

additional_notes: The page number '19' is present in the bottom right corner.
The text 'hibition, see the ter 9.06.030' appears to be a partial or cut-off sentence, likely 'prohibition, see Chapter 9.06.030'.
cross_references: Chapter 9.06.030 (referenced for details on wood-burning fireplace prohibition)
